snowflake.core

Class Chunk

  • java.lang.Object
    • snowflake.core.Chunk
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    j3l.util.check.IValidate, IChunk

    public final class Chunk
extends java.lang.Object
implements IChunk

    A chunk represents a part of the stored data provided by the storage. Its start-address and its length uniquely identify a chunk. There won't be any other chunk with the same start-address.

    A chunk includes the data in the storage at the addresses from #start_adress to #start_adress + length - 1.

    A chunk must never be part of more than one flake. If it would the data this chunk includes would be shared by more than one flake and could possibly cause irrepairable damage to the whole storage.

    It can either be part of a flake or be free. A free chunk will be managed and possibly assigned to a flake by the storage.

    Since:
    JDK 1.8
    Version:
    2016.03.10_0
    Author:
    Johannes B. Latzel

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private IChunkMemory chunk_memory
      used for saving
      private long chunk_table_index
      index in the chunk_table
      private boolean is_valid
      states if this chunk is valid
      private long length
      the amount of bytes this chunks includes
      private boolean needs_to_be_cleared
      indicates if the chunk is currently marked for clearing
      private long position_in_flake
      the unique position inside the flake - This position will always be unique for the specific flake.
      private long start_address
      the unique start-address points directly to the begin-position of the data this chunk represents in the storage.

      • position_in_flake

        private long position_in_flake

        the unique position inside the flake - This position will always be unique for the specific flake.

        If this chunk is not part of a flake than this field must have a negative value to state that it is a free chunk.

    • Method Detail

      • isNeighbourOf

        public boolean isNeighbourOf(Chunk chunk)

        states if this chunk is a logical neighbour to the parameter chunk

        Two chunks are logical neighbours if the start-address + length of one chunk is equal to the start-address of the other chunk.

        Parameters:
        chunk - another chunk
        Returns:
        true if they are neighbour, false otherwise
